pullRequest.body:
Add a definition `List.Triplewise`, for a predicate on a list determined by a predicate on triples of distinct elements.

This is intended in particular for geometrical properties such as betweenness, and was originally suggested by YaÃ«l in 2021: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/circular.20predicate (definition adapted from there for Lean 4, and some API added).

There is undoubtedly lots more API that could be added, but what I have here is sufficient for at least one geometrical use case: defining a list of points being weakly in order on a line and proving that this definition is equivalent to the list of points being the image under a `lineMap` of an ordered list of values in the underlying field.


---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [06487e4d0c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21936/commits/06487e4d0c2e991069c6b36e42e9f8bdf291e849)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Data.List.Triplewise` (new file)|37|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Triplewise`
`+ Triplewise.imp`
`+ Triplewise.map`
`+ Triplewise.of_map`
`+ triplewise_append`
`+ triplewise_cons`
`+ triplewise_iff_getElem`
`+ triplewise_map`
`+ triplewise_pair`
`+ triplewise_reverse`
`+ triplewise_singleton`
`+ triplewise_triple`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Added `triwise_iff_getElem` as requested (named by analogy to `pairwise_iff_getElem`).
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
cc: @eric-wieser, since we discussed something similar in the past

> since we discussed something similar in the past

Indeed, we discussed the analogs of this definition for `Set.Pairwise` and `_root_.Pairwise`. I think it would be nice to have all three with associated API, but I can contribute something towards the other ones.

I'm generally happy with this PR besides being uncertain about `Triwise` vs `Tripletwise`
Added `tripletwise_append` and `tripletwise_reverse`.

What do you think about skipping straight to the n-ary version? At some point we'll presumably want "no four points form a plane" or something. That could look like:
```lean
/-- Whether a predicate holds for all ordered `n`-tuples of elements of a list.

Note that we need `Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) n)` not just `Function.OfArity Î± Prop n` because of universe polymorphism issues.
In practice, that means every predicate must take one final dummy argument.
-/
inductive List.Tupletwise {Î± : Type u} : âˆ€ {n} (p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) n), List Î± â†’ Prop
  /-- For zero-tuples, tupletwise means the property is just true -/
  | of_true {l : List Î±} {p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) 0} (h : p .unit) : l.Tupletwise (n := 0) p
  /-- For non-empty tuples, the property is always true on empty lists. -/
  | nil : [].Tupletwise (n := n + 1) p
  /-- For non-empty tuples, the property is true on `a :: l` if it is true on `l` and the `a`-curried version is also true on `l`. -/
  | cons {a : Î±} {l : List Î±} {n} {p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) (n + 1)} :
      l.Tupletwise (n := n) (p a) â†’ (l.Tupletwise (n := n + 1)) p â†’ (a :: l).Tupletwise (n := n + 1) p

theorem List.Tupletwise.prop {Î± : Type u} {l : List Î±} {p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) 0} (h : l.Tupletwise p) :
    p .unit :=
  match h with
  | of_true h => h

theorem List.Tupletwise.forall {Î± : Type u} {l : List Î±} {p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) 1} (h : l.Tupletwise p) :
    âˆ€ x âˆˆ l, p x .unit :=
  match h with
  | .nil => by simp
  | .cons head tail => forall_mem_cons.mpr âŸ¨head.prop, tail.forallâŸ©

theorem List.Tupletwise.of_forall {Î± : Type u} {l : List Î±} {p : Î± â†’ Prop} (h : âˆ€ x âˆˆ l, p x) :
    l.Tupletwise (n := 1) fun x _ => p x  :=
  match l with
  | .nil => .nil
  | .cons _ _ => let âŸ¨h1, h2âŸ© := forall_mem_cons.mp h; .cons (.of_true h1) <| .of_forall h2

theorem List.Tupletwise.pairwise {Î± : Type u} {l : List Î±} {p : Function.OfArity Î± (PUnit.{u + 1} â†’ Prop) 2} (h : l.Tupletwise p) :
    l.Pairwise (fun x y => p x y .unit) :=
  match h with
  | .nil => .nil
  | .cons head tail => .cons head.forall tail.pairwise

theorem List.Tupletwise.of_pairwise {Î± : Type u} {l : List Î±} {p : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Prop} (h : l.Pairwise p) :
    l.Tupletwise (n := 2) fun x y _ => p x y :=
  match h with
  | .nil => .nil
  | .cons head tail => .cons (.of_forall head) (.of_pairwise tail)
```
though the `PUnit` in `Function.OfArity` is a little unfortunate.

Even without an extra argument (and I think it's definitely desirable to be able to use existing predicates with such operations without needing an extra argument), I expect the concrete lemmas you get for specific arity (and, sometimes, having a number of hypotheses that depends on the arity) will always be more convenient to work with than lemmas stated in an arity-generic form.

I don't rule out that it might be possible to construct such lemmas (for each fixed arity, including `Pairwise`) using metaprogramming in some way rather than needing to state them all explicitly for each arity, but still getting each lemma for each arity stated in a convenient form for that arity. And, yes, we might eventually want `Quadrupletwise` lemmas.
Is `Function.OfArity` necessary here? My experiences with it have only ever been negative, it seems like `(Fin n â†’ Î±) â†’ Î²` is strictly nicer to work with.

Woah, that's ancient. Thank you for reviving!

Do you think you could prove that this is equivalent to the titular definition in terms of ordered triples of indices? Something like
```
lemma triwise_iff_forall_get :
  l.triwise p â†” âˆ€ i j k, i < j â†’ j < k â†’ p l[i] l[j] l[k]
```

Thanks! ðŸš€

maintainer merge
How hard is `l.reverse.Tripletwise p â†” l.Tripletwise fun a b c => p c b a` to prove?

If you do
```suggestion
@[mk_iff]
inductive Triwise (p : Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Î± â†’ Prop) : List Î± â†’ Prop
```

... then you should be able to do
```suggestion
lemma triwise_cons : (a :: l).Triwise p â†” l.Pairwise (p a) âˆ§ l.Triwise p := by
  simp [triwise_iff]
```
This suggested proof doesn't actually work.
Fixed
Is "triwise" a word? I'd expect to see it written `tripletwise`, at least in a docstring if that's too long for a name. After all, we say "pairwise" not "biwise".

OK, I've renamed it to `Tripletwise` everywhere. (The original name was just taken from YaÃ«l's suggestion on Zulip.)

As for `Set` and `_root_` definitions, they're not relevant for my current use case but they seem reasonable to add separately anyway. (There would be other geometrical uses for such definitions; for example, "a set of points is collinear iff they are tripletwise collinear".)
I take the blame for the silly name
`triple` is the usually mathematical term, not `triplet`, no?
Similarly below, it's definitely not `tuplet`, just `tuple`.
You're quite right, musical naming was sneaking in there.

Renamed now to `Triplewise`.

We have "tuple"s in mathlib, they're `Fin n â†’ Î±`. (I think polygons built on tuples will end up being a more convenient way of talking about cyclic polygons than something built on lists, and while such things could be defined in terms of either `Triplewise` (all points on same circle and all triples in the same cyclic order) or `Quadruplewise` (all quadruples are cyclic quadrilaterals), more convenient definitions in that case probably won't be based on those predicates.)

A little easier to induct on `hl` directly:
```suggestion
  induction hl with
  | nil => exact .nil
  | cons head tail ih => exact .cons (head.imp h) ih
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/List/Triplewise): `List.Triplewise`
